results.content: First of all, I must say, this course is UNIQUE. The amount of pain author has taken just to get us getting started is exceptional, and I am giving 5 stars for that. Didn't have the audacity to take any star away due to the nature and content of the course, but for my taste, I kind of started losing way towards the end of the course, and after a certain time just was waiting for it to get over. How I would recommend others to take this course is to go slow, and don't try to learn too many patterns at the same time. Slow, practiced approach is the key here. Hats off!

results.content:
Great course! Covers a lot of the really advanced subjects in a far more practical way than just reading React's docs. I appreciate the step-by-step follow along approach to the course, and Ohans is a great teacher. In particular, he nails the WHY behind design patterns in a way that is memorable. 

Only critique is a bit double edged. I like that Ohans makes mistakes while he codes and shows how to calmly troubleshoot the issue. That said, Ohans occasionally mixes "intentional" mistakes (to illustrate a particular nuance or subtlety that is important for learning) with some honest mistakes. If your style is following along and excitedly checking the result before watching to the end of a lesson, you may find yourself scratching your head for a while, only to realize the error is expected. Not a huge deal once you get through a few lessons, but would love a more "predictable" cadence for when things will work or not work.
results.content_html:
Great course! Covers a lot of the really advanced subjects in a far more practical way than just reading React's docs. I appreciate the step-by-step follow along approach to the course, and Ohans is a great teacher. In particular, he nails the WHY behind design patterns in a way that is memorable.

Only critique is a bit double edged. I like that Ohans makes mistakes while he codes and shows how to calmly troubleshoot the issue. That said, Ohans occasionally mixes "intentional" mistakes (to illustrate a particular nuance or subtlety that is important for learning) with some honest mistakes. If your style is following along and excitedly checking the result before watching to the end of a lesson, you may find yourself scratching your head for a while, only to realize the error is expected. Not a huge deal once you get through a few lessons, but would love a more "predictable" cadence for when things will work or not work.

results.content: Each video builds on what you've learned so far so it's really easy to understand how each pattern works by the time you have implemented it. There's also a good balance of explaining things that might be unfamiliar to those new to React while keeping the pace fast enough to not bore you if you've fairly experienced.
results.content_html: Each video builds on what you've learned so far so it's really easy to understand how each pattern works by the time you have implemented it. There's also a good balance of explaining things that might be unfamiliar to those new to React while keeping the pace fast enough to not bore you if you've fairly experienced.

results.content: As is stated in the description: this is not a beginner course. He goes quite fast, and sometimes I have a bit of trouble keeping up. He's definitely very skilled at what he's doing and he knows the React framework inside and out. If you're an advanced React developer, and you want to take your skills to the next level, I can definitely recommend this course. You'll learn all about some of the most commonly used design patterns in React. If you're new to React, follow an introductory course first, and create a few sites before starting this one. It's worth the money/time, but it requires a strong familiarity with the basic and advanced React concepts.
results.content_html: As is stated in the description: this is not a beginner course. He goes quite fast, and sometimes I have a bit of trouble keeping up. He's definitely very skilled at what he's doing and he knows the React framework inside and out. If you're an advanced React developer, and you want to take your skills to the next level, I can definitely recommend this course. You'll learn all about some of the most commonly used design patterns in React. If you're new to React, follow an introductory course first, and create a few sites before starting this one. It's worth the money/time, but it requires a strong familiarity with the basic and advanced React concepts.

results.content:
The content of this course was not what I expected. 

The first eight videos are dedicated to cloning a project from github in order to work within an obscure environment so that we can add/modify code in order to see it displayed in stylized format. I get it, it looks nice, but in my humble opinion: it's distracting. 

I understand that this is an advanced course and it's to be expected that not every single thing is to be explained in depth, but cloning a directory and working three directories within a completed project just to get something basic displayed in a box wasn't what I expected when previewing the course.

I began sifting through the rest of other sections and videos and saw that there's a heavy focus on slides and visual analogies in order to help the student to understand the patterns better. This is similar to how Stephen Grider presents his material, but with more of a heavy focus on the analogies.

How a pattern is presented, discussed and executed takes s

response.content:
Hey Steven! I appreciate your feedback - but some honesty helps both of us, just so other students aren’t misguided. 

I know you mean good but come on, only 2 videos in Section 2 talk about setting up your local environment and how the showcase works NOT 8 videos! 

Who would do that??? 

Right after those lessons, we start writing code immediately! Yes, there’s a focus on analogies, but there’s way more content covering the actual implementation and delivery of all patterns discussed. 

Thanks for the review, and best of luck!
response.content_html:
Hey Steven! I appreciate your feedback - but some honesty helps both of us, just so other students aren’t misguided.

I know you mean good but come on, only 2 videos in Section 2 talk about setting up your local environment and how the showcase works NOT 8 videos!

Who would do that???

Right after those lessons, we start writing code immediately! Yes, there’s a focus on analogies, but there’s way more content covering the actual implementation and delivery of all patterns discussed.

Thanks for the review, and best of luck!

results.content:
I've completed the entire course and here are some things that would have made it 5 stars
Improvement Suggestions:
- Varying audio quality throughout the videos
- Despite being an intermediate course on advanced patterns, code structure is not industry standard (having a single file for user, hooks, animation layer, etc.)
- Course organization structure isn't entirely clear it uses a 01 to 10 - not all of the design patterns build on top of each other but some do
results.content_html:

results.content:
There are a number of problems with this course. 

First, it is difficult to understand the person talking. His words slur together and you really have to focus to pick out the words he is using. 

Second, the author uses a system that seems to be built so that the student can code along with the author. This is not the case. The author pastes in massive amounts of data not available to the user in any place that I could find. Essentially, you are just watching a guy code and trying hard to understand what he is saying.

Third, there is no real discussion of patterns or practices that I could gather from the course. The author builds and rebuilds a clap component. He adds things and changes things with no real discussion of goals or theory about how things work. You're just watching a guy code and like every other "course" which does this, it's almost impossible to get anything from it. Even though the course is broken into sections that are supposed to show different patterns, it's really just "Here's some code that I wrote. Works better now."
results.content_html:
There are a number of problems with this course.

First, it is difficult to understand the person talking. His words slur together and you really have to focus to pick out the words he is using.

Second, the author uses a system that seems to be built so that the student can code along with the author. This is not the case. The author pastes in massive amounts of data not available to the user in any place that I could find. Essentially, you are just watching a guy code and trying hard to understand what he is saying.

Third, there is no real discussion of patterns or practices that I could gather from the course. The author builds and rebuilds a clap component. He adds things and changes things with no real discussion of goals or theory about how things work. You're just watching a guy code and like every other "course" which does this, it's almost impossible to get anything from it. Even though the course is broken into sections that are supposed to show different patterns, it's really just "Here's some code that I wrote. Works better now."

results.content:
Chapter about reusable styles don't cover in deepth this topis. Pass on className to parent component is in many situations too simple. We need to pass css classes also for child components.
Other patterns are good and I probbably we don't need something more.

response.content: Hey Marcin, thanks for the review. Depending on how you build your components, you shouldn't have a deep nested tree. With child components you can pass classNames as you say or use a child CSS selector and just one className. Still works. Anyway, thanks for the input!
response.content_html: Hey Marcin, thanks for the review. Depending on how you build your components, you shouldn't have a deep nested tree. With child components you can pass classNames as you say or use a child CSS selector and just one className. Still works. Anyway, thanks for the input!

response.content:
Thanks for the review, Youssef. Glad you liked the teaching method employed in the course but bummed you didn't find yourself getting as much from the course. 

As per complex use case, the reason we spend over an hour implementing the Medium clap is so the problem set is complex enough. 

You're right sometimes concepts are repeated or stretched - but that's to accommodate different student levels and make sure the information is retained. 

I appreciate the review. Will perhaps look a little more into these. Many thanks!
response.content_html:
Thanks for the review, Youssef. Glad you liked the teaching method employed in the course but bummed you didn't find yourself getting as much from the course.

As per complex use case, the reason we spend over an hour implementing the Medium clap is so the problem set is complex enough.

You're right sometimes concepts are repeated or stretched - but that's to accommodate different student levels and make sure the information is retained.

I appreciate the review. Will perhaps look a little more into these. Many thanks!

results.content:
Completed the course "The Complete Guide to Advanced React Component Patterns" by Ohans Emmanuel. He uses metaphor, analogy, and visualization to effectively explain 8 advanced react component design patterns clearly.

A design pattern is a repeatable solution to a commonly occurring problem in software engineering. When I need to design a new react component for work or personal project, I will bring out the 8 patterns and decide which one I can use. I managed to apply some patterns to my current work project.

The course is useful for any frontend developer who wants to build reusable React components with hooks and advanced patterns. For more details, you can refer to my live study notes at https://github.com/chesterheng/advanced-react-patterns
results.content_html:
Completed the course "The Complete Guide to Advanced React Component Patterns" by Ohans Emmanuel. He uses metaphor, analogy, and visualization to effectively explain 8 advanced react component design patterns clearly.

A design pattern is a repeatable solution to a commonly occurring problem in software engineering. When I need to design a new react component for work or personal project, I will bring out the 8 patterns and decide which one I can use. I managed to apply some patterns to my current work project.

The course is useful for any frontend developer who wants to build reusable React components with hooks and advanced patterns. For more details, you can refer to my live study notes at https://github.com/chesterheng/advanced-react-patterns

results.content: There are many advanced concepts involved in this course.  A large part of which involved exposing component internal logic for customization or to override some features, thru which, I have learned neat tricks but I don't get to see these kinds of requirements often in my experiences.  This course also reinforce understanding of useMemo, useLayoutEffect and useEffect in 3 different scenarios, useCallback, useRef vs createRef, refactoring technique from useState to useReducer and other hooks.  Many thanks to the instructor and special thanks to the Udemy team who made good suggestions on next step learnings of various topics of interests.  Senn
results.content_html: There are many advanced concepts involved in this course. A large part of which involved exposing component internal logic for customization or to override some features, thru which, I have learned neat tricks but I don't get to see these kinds of requirements often in my experiences. This course also reinforce understanding of useMemo, useLayoutEffect and useEffect in 3 different scenarios, useCallback, useRef vs createRef, refactoring technique from useState to useReducer and other hooks. Many thanks to the instructor and special thanks to the Udemy team who made good suggestions on next step learnings of various topics of interests. Senn

results.content: The course is entitled "...Use hooks & trusted advanced patterns!" It would be better entitled "Use hooks to aid development of React Components by considering a worked example". It is not about patterns.

response.content:
Hey Tony, thanks for the review. For some reason, the style of teaching employed in the course didn't resonate with you, and that's fine. However, the course is definitely about patterns. I think so, and so does hundreds of students and their associated positive ratings. The course does leverage hooks and trusted advanced patterns as advertised too. 

On worked examples, I think effective learning should be backed up with worthy examples - and that's the approach this course takes. Everything is built from scratch, not copy and paste. Sorry, the course didn't suit your learning style, and thanks again for the review. Cheers.
response.content_html:
Hey Tony, thanks for the review. For some reason, the style of teaching employed in the course didn't resonate with you, and that's fine. However, the course is definitely about patterns. I think so, and so does hundreds of students and their associated positive ratings. The course does leverage hooks and trusted advanced patterns as advertised too.

On worked examples, I think effective learning should be backed up with worthy examples - and that's the approach this course takes. Everything is built from scratch, not copy and paste. Sorry, the course didn't suit your learning style, and thanks again for the review. Cheers.
